comments.commentBody:
i would agree with many that the pass interference call on leber was legit, and the catch seemed ok but the fourth down stop was a terrible call which would have canceled out the opportunity for the next two calls. The ball was 1 yard shy of the first down and then was bobbled and pushed further by the end of the play. not the best moment in ref history.

either way, the vikings put themselves in the position to lose. if they hadn't turned the ball over, they would have run away with that game. the saddest part is that the defense played so well.

The worse team walks away with a win tonight because of execution. until the vikes can execute, they should expect similar disappointment.

Vikings' clock management in final 50 seconds was atrocious.
No sense of urgency. Poor play calling. Twelve men on the field was the fatal blow.
Favre's interception was an anti-climax.
Glad I'm not a Vikings fan.
Those deluded souls who blame the refs are crushing bores.

Eh, I was all fine with Favre for a while since the media wasn't slobbering over him for the past few weeks (it's been the Jets, at least in NYC - as you know.)  Honestly, I felt kinda bad for him today as he got beaten to death and threw a pick at the end of regulation.  He did have a great season (although I still say a mediocre QB could lead that Vikings team deep into the playoffs,) especially for his age.  I just get sick of Favre love when people like Tom Jackson say, "I like Brett Favre because he isn't afraid to throw interceptions." After showing Brett Favre throwing what possibly could have been the INT that cost the Vikes the game.  I mean, let's not drool over this guy when he screws up too.

Refs blew the END of the game?
That was possibly one of the worst officiated games in recent memory, start to finish. However, the Saints came out on the short end in terms of gift calls and still won the game. If one thinks that Leber did not commit PI, you're using a set of rules that exists only in dreams.
Meacham clearly caught the ball. What game were you guys watching.  Not a Saints fan, but the catch was clear.

I am not going to speculate on wether or not the Vikings should have won the game or not. The outcome of ANY game is to be determined by the players...on the field...not the refs.

The refs did a terrible job tonight...terrible.

The Saints are going to the Super Bowl...did they deserve it? We'll it appeared to me that they couldn't get there on their own- even with all of the Vikings turnovers...they still needed the refs help.

It would have been nice to see how the game would have played out...without they refs being paid off.

It probably has something to do with all the Vikings playing in Pro Bowl next week...the commission was probably too worried that the game would need to be canceled due to too many of the players heading to the Super Bowl. Greedy.

One camera angle shows clearly that Ben Leber did not interfere with the receiver. I like the Saints, but the ref gave the game to them, and that is a hollow victory. Is there any accountability? The ref has be 100% positve that a foul was committed before he throws the flag. Terible, terrible call. Can't we change this system? Video replay should prove the ref's call 100% of the time by a team of observers so the game can continue at a good pace. If it doesn't, it has be cancelled. And then there is the catch by Meacham. This game was not decided by the Vikings or the Saints ... but by the refs making bad calls ... a travesty.

I don't understand why so many people are so harsh on the Vikings. They lost by a field goal and in overtime. And there were a number of questionable calls against them. Had there not been those questionable calls, they could have won in regulation. They played hard and well, and they may have lost unfairly. The least we spectators can do is not to add hurt to insult.
I def thought the refs in OT ruined it for the Vikings. That pass interference call was the biggest offender. Sad.

I do not watch sports often and when I do, I see games such as this decided by the officials. It seems sad that in some cases a team can play much better and dominate a game only to lose because of nefarious officials.  In this game, I really felt the officials contrived the outcome.

Oh really? Some people will never be happy for us.

40 years this franchise has suffered, this city has watched them fail. and the succeed and this excuse of a news outlet is going to say officials messed it up?

The officials gave us the shaft all game, yet we came out on top.

SAINTS WON! GET OVER IT!

# 24 Noch

Dear Mr. Noch,

You ask whether I would try to clean up the Hudson River knowing of the presence of the PCB's.

You need to ask a dredging expert that question, not me. Is there any way to get rid of river bottom mud without fouling the water above? If the dredger says "No", then we know that dredging is bound to make things worse, not better.

First, do no harm.

It is the cardinal rule in medicine, and I believe it should be the cardinal rule in environmentalism as well.

It may be that present technology does not allow us to fix this chronic problem without turning it into a major acute problem.

If so, then a third option must be considered: monitor the chronic problem while efforts continue to develop new technology that would give us feasible methods to deal with it. What might that be? As I understand it, tort law would suggest that it is the party who caused the nuisance -GE- which would be obligated to develop, say, methods to incapsulate the deposits with cofferdams of impervious concrete.

But good intentions are not enough. Polluting a river in a bungled attempt to clean up that same river has not inspired, in me, any great admiration for the logic or technical competence of either the EPA or the NRDC.

Re:#53

Mr. Craft;
Not that far behind you - still, don’t see any need to get early jump on the embalming process.
I’ve posted it here before, but for more unrelated-random-food-sterilization info, search “fluoride sterilization,” “birth control water supply,” “soy milk birth control,” “plastic food beverage packaging hormone disruptor,” “rising food allergies.”

they totally did!!! so many times, what is unbelievable is that the vikings didn't challenge the play P. Thomas run for a NON touchdown.. one official marked the ball was dead in yd.1 (which is clearly what happened) while the other official saw an inexistent TD.. no challenge. with that and all the turnovers it is impossible to end in the SB.

Ball possession, accurate and timely distribution, making things happen were a missing quality with the USMNT.  The players that were fielded displayed nothing resembling  quality and team shape  on both sides of the ball. Mr. Bell was extremely generous with the ratings. Most of the fielded players looked tentative, unsure and technically unable to cope.  Lesson learned? I have doubts.

Yes, Favre threw an unfortunate, fateful pass in O.T.  But Brees and company got in position to score with the assist of a markedly biased team of refs.  The refs all but turned their backs as Favre was repeatedly pounded into the ground (i.e. roughing the passer).  The Viking receivers were interfered with and Saints incomplete passes were miraculously complete - even upon review!  Go Colts!

comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
Alexis #57

"It probably has something to do with all the Vikings playing in Pro Bowl next week...the commission was probably too worried that the game would need to be canceled due to too many of the players heading to the Super Bowl. Greedy."

This is quite possibly the funniest thing I've read all day... it's so ludicrous it's hilarious. If the Vikings players were unavailable for the ProBowl the game wouldn't be cancelled, replacement ProBowlers would be named. I still got a good chuckle out of it though.

As for the cries of "cheap shots" against the Saints defense... really which game were you folks watching? About the most questionable hit on Favre was the one to the back of his knees... but even then I didn't think it was egregious enough to say that the intent was there to deliberately hurt him.

I was just passively listening to the OT as I worked on something else (after watching most of regulation, go figure) so I can't really comment on the calls in controversy. Part of me was rooting for the Vikes, Favre and Peterson in particular to redeem themselves though. Peterson did with his three TDs... Favre? *sigh* Same old Brett Favre.

Are you guys Favre's personal security service? Give me a break - the Saints had WAY more penalties than the Vikings and as somebody has already noted, got shafted on several calls (most notably in the 3rd quarter for a completely legit hit on Favre). Meachem legit caught the pass. The one sketchy call that benefited the Saints was the TD ruling following Payton's challenge...it seemed iffy that he was in the endzone from the angles they showed (and certainly not the irrefutable evidence required to overturn a call on the field). I understand the Vikings have a rough history, but please - when you have that many turnovers and a cocky QB who manages to always make it about him ("serious ankle injury" - you aren't playing anything if you're seriously injured, he was clearly fine), you're not an impressive team. Brett Favre cost his team the game. End of story.

Puh-leeeze. I don't know about the rules change (or not) for the first pass, but I've seen the Hail Mary pass hundreds of times, and there was no pass interference whatsoever. It stands as one of the great moments in sports history.
Why let a coin toss decide the first possession of OT. Clearly an outdated rule. Let both teams have a shot before going to sudden death, at least. Or just let the visitors receive!

I never saw any contact in that pass interference call. The receiver sure fell down spectacularly. The officials looked to me to be way sympathetic to the Saints.
I'm still wondering why the booth reviewed the spot of the ball after a measurement came up short of a Saints first down.
The Saints were brutal in their play and deserved all the penalties they did receive - and more. I am a Saints fan.
Favre played heroically, but yeh, sure, he threw the interception.

The bad officiating did not only occur in OT.I'm not a vikings or NO fan but can't help but feel angry on behalf of the vikings. And who ever was in the booth needs their eyes examined.The hits on the QB should have resulted in more personal fouls. The officials seemed to encourage roughing the passer by letting them go without a foul. That TD at the 1 the field refs had correct. How they overturned it
I can't understand. Granted NO would most likely have made it on the next play but the call was still wrong. that wasn't a TD, period.

yes, the vikings made more errors by far than NO but they were still in the game. To make that many mistakes and still be in there all the way speaks volumes to their ability. They were the better team but the refs were not on their side. And yes, Favre made an ill advised pass but it's incredible he was even able to stand and play at that point after all the uncalled personal fouls. NO had plenty of time to move the ball and Minn stopped them repeatedly. Favre took hit after hit, limping off in the 3rd, and kept coming back for more. It's a shame it ended the way it did.

Saints will get blown away by the Colts if the officials don't muck up the game like they did this one. The Saints didn't win, the Vikings lost. Hard to win with that many turnovers and and a set of officials that seemed to be watching a different game than the fans. Clearly the vikings defender didn't interfere with the receiver and has no obligation to turn around and face the ball when the ball is not near - which it wasn't (i.e., not catchable). Phantom first downs and catches.

NFL officiating has been and always will be rank amateurs who think they should decided the game, which they did this time again.
Farce tried to force plays, for that he paid the price. Turnovers were rediculous. Still, there was very poor officiating. Bordering on the negligent.

Don't supose anyone thought to actually look at penalty stats. By the end of the 3rd quarter Saints penalties= 9 for 80 yards Viks=2 for 10 Hmmmm. If you don't put yourself in a position where close calls matter, then they won't matter. As far as roughing the QB-short memories for some posters here. Brees was lifted and slammed in the 4th without complaint or flag and just like Favre, he got back up and played football-it's their job. Watch golf if the game is too rough for you. No offense to Tiger Woods.
